Class Particle

  • java.lang.Object
    • Particle

  • public class Particle
extends java.lang.Object
    The Particle class represents a particle moving in the unit box, with given position, velocity, radius, and mass. Methods are provided for moving the particle and simulating elastic collisions with vertical walls, horizontal walls, and other particles.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Particle()
      Initializes a particle with random position and velocity.
      Particle(double rx, double ry, double vx, double vy, double radius, double mass, java.awt.Color color)
      Initializes a Particle with given specified parameters.

      Updates the velocities of this and that particle acccording to the laws of elastic collision.
      void bounceOffHorizontalWall()
      Updates the velocity of this particle upon collision with a Horizontal wall.
      void bounceOffVerticalWall()
      Updates the velocity of this particle upon collision with a Vertical wall.
      int count()
      Returns the total number of collisions involving this particle.
      void draw()
      Draws this particle to the Standard Draw.
      double kineticEnergy()
      Returns the kinetic energy of this particle.
      static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
      For unit testing of the class Particle.java
      void move(double dt)
      Move this particle on a straight with its velocity for specified time.
      static boolean radiusUpscalingEnabled()
      Returns true if radius upscaling is enabled.
      void setDefaultColor(java.awt.Color newColor)
      Set new default color for randomly generated particles.
      double timeToHit(Particle that)
      Returns the time required by this particle to collide with that particle.
      double timeToHitHorizontalWall()
      Returns the time until this particle hits a Horizontal wall assuming no Intervening collision.
      double timeToHitVerticalWall()
      Returns the time until this particle hits a Vertical swall assuming no Intervening collision.
      static void useRadiusUpscaling(boolean yes)
      If this setting is turned on, small sized particles are upscaled to minimum observable radius onscreen which otherwise might be invisible due to extremely small size.

      • Particle

        public Particle(double rx,
                double ry,
                double vx,
                double vy,
                double radius,
                double mass,
                java.awt.Color color)
        Initializes a Particle with given specified parameters.
        Parameters:
        rx - x coordinate of the position
        ry - y coordinate of the position
        vx - x component of the velocity
        vy - y component of the velocity
        radius - the radius
        mass - the mass
        color - the color

        Returns the total number of collisions involving this particle.

      • timeToHit

        public double timeToHit(Particle that)
        Returns the time required by this particle to collide with that particle.

        If you don't understand the Physics used here. Refer this book-site, Algorithms 4th Edition

        I am doing this project as an exercise after reading that book.

        Parameters:
        that - the other particle.
        Returns:
        the time required for collision between this particle and that particle

      • timeToHitHorizontalWall

        public double timeToHitHorizontalWall()
        Returns the time until this particle hits a Horizontal wall assuming no Intervening collision.
        Returns:
        the time until this particle hits a Horizontal wall assuming no Intervening collision

      • timeToHitVerticalWall

        public double timeToHitVerticalWall()
        Returns the time until this particle hits a Vertical swall assuming no Intervening collision.
        Returns:
        the time until this particle hits a Vertical wall assuming no Intervening collision

      • bounceOff

        public void bounceOff(Particle that)
        Updates the velocities of this and that particle acccording to the laws of elastic collision. Assumes the particles collide at this moment.

        If you don't understand the Physics used here. Refer this book-site, Algorithms 4th Edition

        I am doing this project as an exercise after reading that book.

        Parameters:
        that -

      • bounceOffVerticalWall

        public void bounceOffVerticalWall()
        Updates the velocity of this particle upon collision with a Vertical wall. Assumes the collision is undergoing at this instant. Reflects the x-component of the velocity.

      • bounceOffHorizontalWall

        public void bounceOffHorizontalWall()
        Updates the velocity of this particle upon collision with a Horizontal wall. Assumes that the paricle collides with the wall at this instant. Reflects the velocity in y-direction.

      • kineticEnergy

        public double kineticEnergy()
        Returns the kinetic energy of this particle.
        Returns:
        the kinetic energy of this particle

      • setDefaultColor

        public void setDefaultColor(java.awt.Color newColor)
        Set new default color for randomly generated particles. Does NOT do anything for particles constructed with specific colors.
        Parameters:
        newColor - the new default color for random particles

      • useRadiusUpscaling

        public static void useRadiusUpscaling(boolean yes)
        If this setting is turned on, small sized particles are upscaled to minimum observable radius onscreen which otherwise might be invisible due to extremely small size.

        By default this is disabled.

        Parameters:
        yes - if true up-scaling is enabled, other not.

      • radiusUpscalingEnabled

        public static boolean radiusUpscalingEnabled()
        Returns true if radius upscaling is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if radius upscaling is enabled

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing of the class Particle.java
        Parameters:
        args - the command line arguments
